titleStmt.title: Tamiḻneṟi Viḷakkam 25.
Experimenting with formatting for the final edition.

witness.expan: A Critical Edition and Study of Akapporul Vilakkam [ante correctionem]
A Critical Edition and Study of Akapporul Vilakkam [post correctionem]

div.p: [The confidante's] refusal [of the bard] at the door; [the bard] speaking at the door; the confidante rebuking [the bard]; [the bard's] vexaion appearing; the hero becoming vexed; the heroine becoming vexed; [the heroine] saying "He, the lover, does not desire me"; the mother seeing [this] and speaking; and other [situations] which exist because of enduring love [are] 'the separation to 'that place''This, as is made clear in the comentary, is a way to refer to the hero's separation when he is visiting his extramarital lover, whose character I render in English as 'the other woman'. It is not clear however, exactly how to translate the phrase āyiṭai pirivu. The most common translations are 'intermediate-distance separation' or 'separation to that place'. I prefer the second in part due to its ambiguity. For the sake of clarity, āyiṭai is a combination of the deictic prefix 'a' (that, there) and the noun 'iṭai' (place). Both convey the idea that this separation is both short-term, at least compared to the long-distance version mentioned in the previous cūttiram, and short-distance, as the hero's other woman is understood to live in the same town as the hero and heroine by theoreticians. The translation 'that place' allows for an elliptical reference to the fact that he is going somewhere he shouldn't by stepping out of his marital home, and it also keeps open the possibility that it can be a separation to a place that is right there.
eṉpatu āy iṭaip pirivām āṟuṇarttutaṉutaliṟṟu.
The quoted [cūttiram] intends to make known the way in which 'the separation to 'that place'' occurs.
vāyiṉ maṟuttal mutal ākac cevili kūṟṟīṟākac collap paṭṭa vivaiyum piṟavum parattaiyiṟ pirivām eṉṟa vāṟu.
Beginning with the refusal at the door and ending with the foster-mother's speech, these which have been mentioned and other are [the situations of] 'the separation on account of the other woman'.
piṟavum eṉṟataṉāṟ parattaiyar kūṟṟum pūppuṇarttutalum uḷ ḷiṭṭaṉa vellāṅ koḷka.
Because he says piṟavum, understand that they include all of the speeches of the other woman and making known the menstruation.
eṉpatu pāṇaṉukku vāyiṉ maṟuttatu.
[The confidante] refuses [entry] to the bard at the door.
eṉpatu vāyiṉ maṟukkappaṭṭa pāṇaṉ kūṟiyatu.
The bard, who had been refused at the door, speaks.
eṉpatu viṟali vāyiṉ maṟuttatu.
The dancing-girl refuses [the bard] at the door.
eṉpatu tōḻikku vāyiṉ maṟuttatu.
[The bard] refutes the confidante at the door.
eṉpatu vāyiṉ maṟuttamai tōḻi talaimakaṟkuc colliyatu.
The confidante speaks to the hero about the [the bard's] refusal at the door.
eṉpatu vāyil peṟāta talaimakaṉ vāṭiyatu.
The hero, who had not obtained [entry] at the door, grieves.
eṉpatu talaimakaḷ āṟṟāmai kaṇṭūṭal uṇarttac cellun tōḻi colliyatu.
After seeing the heroine unable to bear [the situation], the conifdante, who had gone to resolve [the lovers'] quarrel, speaks [to the hero].
eṉpatu tōḻi...

standOff.note: Cf. TP148i.25-26: pāṇar kūttar viṟaliya reṉṟivar | pēṇic colliya kuṟaiviṉai yetiru |
Cf. TP154i: uṇarppuvarai yiṟappiṉuñ ceykuṟi piḻaippiṉum | pulattalu mūṭaluṅ kiḻavōṟ kuriya ||
Cf. TP488i.4-5:... pulaviyu mūṭalu muṇarvum | pirivoṭu puṇarntatu kaṟpeṉap paṭumē ||
Cf. IA47: kiḻavōṉ muṉṉark kiḻatti kaṟpukaḻtal | pulavik kālattum puraiva taṉṟē ||
Cf. IA48: nāṭum ūrum illum cuṭṭit | taṉvayiṉ kiḷappiṉ pulavip poruṭṭē ||
Cf. TP44i.22-24: parattaiyi ṉakaṟciyiṟ parintōṭ kuṟuki | yirattalun teḷittalu meṉaviru vakaiyō | ṭuraittiṟ nāṭṭaṅ kiḻavōṉ mēṉa ||
Cf. IA40: kātaṟ parattai ellārkkum urittē ||
Cf. IA43: parattaiyiṟ pirinta kiḻavōṉ maṉaivi | pūppiṉ puṟappā ṭīraṟu nāḷum | nīttakaṉ ṟuṟaital aṟattā ṟaṉṟē ||
Cf. IAC43, p.179: aḵtāmāṟuː talaimakaṉ parattiyiṟpirinta kālattut talaimakaṭku pūpput tōṉṟiṟṟu; tōṉṟat, talaimkaṉ uṇarum. eṅṅaṉam uṇarumō eṉiṉ, vvayilkaḷ uṇartta uṇarum eṉpatu.
